document.docAuthor: Stonis, Jonas R., Diškus, Arūnas, Remeikis, Andrius, Davis, Donald R., Solis, M. Alma & Torres, Nixon Cumbicus
document.docTitle: Stigmella emarginatae Diskus & Stonis, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: The first record of Baccharis L. (Asteraceae) as a host-plant genus for Nepticulidae (Lepidoptera), with description of new Stigmella species from South America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The first record of Baccharis L. (Asteraceae) as a host-plant genus for Nepticulidae (Lepidoptera), with description of new Stigmella species from South America

heading.emphasis:
1 .
Stigmella emarginatae Diškus & Stonis
, sp. nov.

. Holotype : ♂, ECUADOR : Tungurahua Province, Baños,
1 ° 23 ' 44 "S
,
78 ° 26 ' 14 "W
, elevation 1855 m , mining larvae on
Baccharis emarginata (Ruiz & Pav.) Pers .

, field card no. 4911 , leg. A. Diškus, genitalia slide no. AD
600 ♂
( ZMUC ). Paratypes :
2 ♂
, 1 ♀, same locality as holotype ,
10 .ii. 2007
,
9.xi. 2007
, field cards nos 4850, 4911 , genitalia slides nos AD
603 ♂
, AD 602 ♀ ( ZMUC ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 15–19. Genitalia of
Stigmella emarginatae Diškus & Stonis
,
sp. nov.
(ZMUC). 15–17, phallus, paratype, genitalia slide no. AD603; 18, capsule without phallus, dorsal view, holotype, genitalia slide no. AD600; 19, female genitalia, paratype, genitalia slide no. AD602.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The new species differs from all other known Neotropical
Stigmella
in the combination of large apical processes of the valva, 5–6 very large cornuti of the phallus, sublaterally pointed transtilla, and the large central plate of the gnathos in the male genitalia. The host-plant (
Baccharis emarginata
) is also distinctive for this species.

Distribution (
Fig. 3
). This species occurs in the equatorial Andes ( Ecuador : Tungurahua Province) at altitudes between 1800–2000 m (
Figs 3
, 4 ).

Etymology. The species is named after the host-plant
Baccharis emarginata .
